docs.lead_paragraph: In debates, and particularly in the health care debate, facts are not sufficient. President Obama needs to move Americans with passion, conviction and faith.

docs.lead_paragraph: The unemployment rate surged to 9.7 percent in August, signaling that joblessness and financial anxiety were likely to endure in millions of American homes for many months. The Labor Department's latest employment report, released Friday, added weight to a growing belief that, at least technically, the economy had already escaped the grip of recession. Though 216,000 net jobs vanished in August, the losses continued to moderate from their worst numbers of the year.

headline.main: Unemployment Hits 9.7% Despite Slower Job Losses

docs.abstract: Labor Dept reports that 216,000 net jobs vanished in August and unemployment rate surged to 9.7% from 9.4% in July; report adds weight to growing belief that economy has escaped grip of recession, as job losses continued to moderate from their worst numbers of year; report also lends credence to consensus that recovery was likely to be weak, prompting most companies to hold back from aggressive hiring; charts; photos (M)

byline.original: By PETER S. GOODMAN and JACK HEALY

docs.lead_paragraph: In his speech, with which he hopes to reclaim the health care debate, President Obama will be far more ''prescriptive'' in detailing what he wants in the final legislation, his aides indicate. But that raises a question: Should the Obama administration have delivered its own legislative package at the beginning of this process, rather than leaving the details to various Congressional committees?
docs.abstract: Many of Pres Obama's supporters cite Clinton administration's health care debacle as proof that legislation drawn up by executive branch would alienate power brokers on Capitol Hill, but former Pres Bill Clinton has argued that blaming his decision to hand health care bill to Congress is inaccurate depiction of what occurred; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Labor Day weekend may be fairly labor-intensive for anyone watching the debate on health care. With President Obama's health care speech to Congress coming on Wednesday, various interest groups are stepping up their pressure to try to influence his thinking.
docs.abstract: Various interest groups are trying to influence Pres Obama before he gives his health care speech to Congress; photo (S)
